Comment: Before the hunt, they should not swear using e.g. words for private parts women/men, otherwise an accident will happen. Nuno = 4 days before the hunt starts they say a kind of prayer and offer food and drink to ancestors so that the hunt will go well. When the hunt starts, they do Lɜgɜ' (= to press): They put money tobacco and silk on the biggest rock / under the biggest tree as an offering so that the hunt will go well.
There are some parallellisms, e.g. the word to propose marriage (see above)
There is not really a separate ritual language. Everyone can understand the language that is used in rituals.
Liã = half circle dance, also the name of the song accompanying it, and a mantra. Sole = full circle dance, also the name of the song accompanying it.
Some young people that have stayed in the village know it; young people that have studied or worked elsewhere, don't know it.
Sili' = war dance, only for men. Hedũ and Sole Liã for women and men (to find a partner), Gawe Au ('step bamboo'): only for women. (In Solor the men can also dance this.)
Yes there is one dance where they are separated. When they do ann offering in the corner of the rumah adat, women are not allowed to come in.
Ceremony Pa'o Bani is before planting and harvesting. (pa'o = feed, bani = altar)
Called Kelaki Ado Pehã from Lembata.
see above
The rumah adat, and the altar noba nara, and the square in front of the rumah adat Namã (= kind of dance, other name for Sole dance).

They were sitting on the back of a crocodile using it as a boat. Adonara people have a special relation with elephants: they will never harm anyone from Adonara, and when an Adonara person talks to them, they will listen when they get an offering. They should not be killed.
The ancestor man came from a mountain in Lembata and the woman from a mountain in Adonara.
They are called kebe'le = big.
arak, tuak, sirih pinang, tobacco. (Honey, marak = tuak from coconut, drank when people are sick.)
Called Nubo Nara
But there is the ritual 4 days after birth (see above).
4 days after a person dies and is buried, the family is baptized with coconut oil and they get a blessing from one of the elders in the family. This is called Toto Dulat.

When they hear a civet cat (defender of the clan) crying it means the ancestors need food. They offer chicken and rice to the ancestors/saints (Nuba Nara) and to Rera Wula (sun moon) (= God?) on the Pa'o Nuba Nara = altar. This ritual is also done before they build the rumah adat.
In Lemat no pottery is produced but in Lamakera in Solor they make pottery. (Kera = bucket to fetch water from the well.)
Gambus (guitar), Gõ Bawa (gong drum); played e.g. when a new rumah adat is build.
Not special for this village.
With hard rock from the sea (not corral rock)
Long hair for men bound on top of the head with a knot on top of it.
Gola: round earrings of besi putih for guys to wear in the ears. Not practiced anymore. Nowadays only women have earrings.
Nile bala (ivory), nile kasido, nile tana; nile = necklace. Coconut leaves used like a crown (for men) called Kenobo, with Senai (slendang).
See above
see above

north: rai, west: lali, east: teti, south: lau. In Witi Hama, a village on the other side of the mountain, south: rai, east: teti, west: lali, north: lau. So the directional system is directed towards the mountain, not absolute.
there is a tree called Kepara, which has two genders: male and female. The wood of the female is used for a ritual to sweep a grave every day after the burrial, till the ceremony on day 4.
Lamaholot, B Indonesia, B Malayu
B Indonesia, B Malayu, Lamaholot
Use Lamaholot, or language of the other
If the wife is not from here she must learn Lmh
If the husband is not from here, he learns Lmh
In the beginning they may use Indonesian or Melayu as intermediate language
During musim kemarau (May-Oct) with dogs, using bow and arrow, and machete
With a large net that is left in the sea for several days
pig, goat, chicken (no cows)
Mostly 1-6 km from the village
Corn (only Oct-Jan), cassava, beans, coconut; fruits: banana, mangga, papaya.
Mostly corn, coconut and mangoes
In Lewat there are 5 clans: Sanga Na'e, Gede Na'e, Lia Na'e, Lasã Na'e, Atamuki. (Bpk Kerung is from Atamuki.)
Each clan has its own traditional house.

The highest one is Gede Na'e, the remaining 4 are equal in rank. Gede Na'e has the kepala kampung, which is like a president of all the clans. Each of the other clans have their own leader (ketua suku). Gede Na'e may be the leading clan because they were the first to migrate from Ria Wale in the mountains to Niha One and then to Lewat.
Land is considered the mother = source of life.
Kepala kampung = Lawo Alate (lawo 'kampung', alate 'owner') is the tuan tanah.

Sawah/field/garden: divided between the sons. Rumah adat (if father is kepala suku): the title and the house goes to the eldest son. Ivory goes to eldest son. Kain tenun divided between sons and daughters (daughters optional). In general the youngest son gets the least and daughters do not inherit.
Women are excluded. They become part of the clan of their husband. That clan receives the belis.
Only kain tenun, optional, if there are enough of them.

Newcomers cannot buy garden, cannot buy land to build a house. Land belongs to the original people as the source of their life. Newcomers are only allowed a temporary house, and cannot join traditional ceremonies except marriage.

20-30 men (most around 24); 16-28 women (most around 18) In the 1970's it was the custom that men married between 30-40+, women 20-30+. Now it is 20+ for men, 15+ for women.The reason that the age was higher earlier may be the price of the belis, and the fact that man and woman could already live together without being married in church.

1. Certain clans do not marry each other (not in Lewat but in neighbouring villages). If it happens the belis is not paid. Types of marriage: Gete-Dahã 'ask-ask': ask for woman, proper way. Pɜla'e: Kawin lari, marriage without parent's permission. Bɜluwo: forced marriage because woman is pregnant. Bote: Woman is kidnapped (because she doesn't agree; her parents may or may not agree.) This is the worst way to get married and it is no longer practised.
In church they exchange rings. But they do not exchange food/drink.
There is no bride service but if belis is not yet paid, it is utang, and the debt will remain and be inherited by the children.
Wife moves to husband's group always, even if the bridewealth is not yet paid.
It is possible to marry inside the clan (if not kaka adik) as well as outside the clan. Breũ can be married outside, but also someone from a different clan. Cousins cannot be married.
Paternal/maternal grandparents can both raise the children.
Breũ (cousin that is the child of mother's brother) principle. Mother's brother (opu lake) is most highly respected, as the provider of the mother (=life), and the person to whom belis is paid.
It happens but less so.
Ivory, goat, pig, chicken; It's called weli̚
Kain, bracelets. It called Ohe.
Related men tend to live closer to each other.
4 desa in area Dua Nukin; Lewat, Nia One, Bunga Lawa, Beda Lawon.
yes
Village square, called Basa for each village. In addition there is a space called Sebaõ for many desa; and a Pasang Grahan, a kind of court.
west-east are steaper than north-south
There is a new tradition where they do build an attic.
no
There is a famous war called Paji-Demõ, two regions in Ile Bolɛ that fight about borders. They were arch enemies till the 1960's

The shape of the village is typically that the head of the village is in the direction of the mountain whereas the foot of the village is in the direction of the sea. This might be related to the fact that they believe the original settlement was on the mountain and they migrated away from it. There is one village that has the opposite direction: head towards the sea, feet towards the mountain.
Hereditary
Earlier there were slaves but not anymore. Whether they were hereditary or not we don't know.
Nayu' Baya: treaty to not have war between villages (not clans). Some villages are considered brothers, e.g. Watu Waĩ and Tapu Bale. No barter trade relations. Ivory bought in Tanjung Bunga.
Nayu' Baya: treaty to not have war between villages (not clans).

A baby gets a temporary name (Kopõ Wulã for boy, Sedõ Gurek for girl) for 2-3 days to 1 week, then there is a Golɛ ̃ Lala (sit in a circle- porridge). This ceremony is only held if a child is born at home with a traditional midwife (dukun). Not when it is born in hospital.
Not in Lewat, but there is one clan (Dosin Na'ɛ ̃) that owns two names that cannot be used elsewhere.
First child gets father's family name, the second and third gets either father's or mother's family name. it is a family name, not the name of the clan.
For second or third child, optional.
You should not use the names from clan Dosin Na'ɛ .
Father and mother and Opu must not be called by their first name.
Koda Kiwãne (koda = word, message)
Murike. Derived from the word murĩ 'new'.
